column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=I looked at the man awhile in solid astonishment ; then I says —

#Text=“ Now , I hope you do n’t take it as an offence , for I do n’t mean any , but really , for a man that has been in the Kingdom as long as I reckon you have , you do seem to know powerful little about its customs . ”
#Text=“ Its customs ! ” says he .
#Text=“ Heaven is a large place , good friend .
#Text=Large empires have many and diverse customs .
#Text=Even small dominions have , as you doubtless know by what you have seen of the matter on a small scale in the Wart .
#Text=How can you imagine I could ever learn the varied customs of the countless kingdoms of heaven ?
#Text=It makes my head ache to think of it .

#Text=I know the customs that prevail in those portions inhabited by peoples that are appointed to enter by my own gate — and hark ye , that is quite enough knowledge for one individual to try to pack into his head in the thirty-seven millions of years I have devoted night and day to that study .
#Text=But the idea of learning the customs of the whole appalling expanse of heaven — O man , how insanely you talk !
#Text=Now I do n’t doubt that this odd costume you talk about is the fashion in that district of heaven you belong to , but you wo n’t be conspicuous in this section without it . ”
#Text=I felt all right , if that was the case , so I bade him good-day and left .
#Text=All day I walked towards the far end of a prodigious hall of the office , hoping to come out into heaven any moment , but it was a mistake .
#Text=That hall was built on the general heavenly plan — it naturally could n’t be small .

#Text=At last I got so tired I could n’t go any farther ; so I sat down to rest , and begun to tackle the queerest sort of strangers and ask for information , but I did n’t get any ; they could n’t understand my language , and I could not understand theirs .
#Text=I got dreadfully lonesome .
#Text=I was so down-hearted and homesick I wished a hundred times I never had died .
#Text=I turned back , of course .
#Text=About noon next day , I got back at last and was on hand at the booking-office once more .
#Text=Says I to the head clerk —
#Text=“ I begin to see that a man ’s got to be in his own Heaven to be happy . ”
#Text=“ Perfectly correct , ” says he .
#Text=“ Did you imagine the same heaven would suit all sorts of men ? ”
#Text=“ Well , I had that idea — but I see the foolishness of it .
#Text=Which way am I to go to get to my district ? ”
#Text=He called the under clerk that had examined the map , and he gave me general directions .
#Text=I thanked him and started ; but he says —
#Text=“ Wait a minute ; it is millions of leagues from here .
#Text=Go outside and stand on that red wishing-carpet ; shut your eyes , hold your breath , and wish yourself there . ”
#Text=“ I ’m much obliged , ” says I ;
#Text=“ why did n’t you dart me through when I first arrived ? ”
#Text=“ We have a good deal to think of here ; it was your place to think of it and ask for it .
#Text=Good-by ; we probably sha’ n’t see you in this region for a thousand centuries or so . ”
#Text=“ In that case , o revoor , ” says I.
#Text=I hopped onto the carpet and held my breath and shut my eyes and wished I was in the booking-office of my own section .
#Text=The very next instant a voice I knew sung out in a business kind of a way —
#Text=“ A harp and a hymn-book , pair of wings and a halo , size 13 , for Cap’n Eli Stormfield , of San Francisco !
#Text=— make him out a clean bill of health , and let him in . ”
#Text=I opened my eyes .

#Text=Sure enough , it was a Pi Ute Injun I used to know in Tulare County ; mighty good fellow — I remembered being at his funeral , which consisted of him being burnt and the other Injuns gauming their faces with his ashes and howling like wildcats .
#Text=He was powerful glad to see me , and you may make up your mind I was just as glad to see him , and feel that I was in the right kind of a heaven at last .

#Text=Just as far as your eye could reach , there was swarms of clerks , running and bustling around , tricking out thousands of Yanks and Mexicans and English and Arabs , and all sorts of people in their new outfits ; and when they gave me my kit and I put on my halo and took a look in the glass , I could have jumped over a house for joy , I was so happy .
#Text=“ Now this is something like ! ” says I. “ Now , ” says I , “ I ’m all right — show me a cloud . ”
#Text=Inside of fifteen minutes I was a mile on my way towards the cloud-banks and about a million people along with me .
#Text=Most of us tried to fly , but some got crippled and nobody made a success of it .
#Text=So we concluded to walk , for the present , till we had had some wing practice .
#Text=We begun to meet swarms of folks who were coming back .

#Text=Some had harps and nothing else ; some had hymn-books and nothing else ; some had nothing at all ; all of them looked meek and uncomfortable ; one young fellow had n’t anything left but his halo , and he was carrying that in his hand ; all of a sudden he offered it to me and says —
